field.name: Publication name
field.definition: the name of the publication in which a published work appears

dos.practice: This field is required for articles, books, monographs, book chapters, book forewords, book reviews, encyclopedia, encyclopedia entries and newsletters. Some resource types like interactive resource may or may not have a publication name.

For AMS conference preprints/proceedings that may contain what appear to be written articles, poster abstracts or slides of the presentation, choose presentation as the title type; choose presented for the status; choose non-refereed as the classification. Do not complete a publication name but do complete an event name. Do not complete pagination information either. Also be sure the written articles and poster abstracts are the versions without the AMS page numbers in order not to violate AMS policies.
If a proceedings is refereed, choose article as the title type; choose published as the status. Then complete both a publication name and event name for the resource.

If a proceedings is non-AMS and non-refereed, the resource could be a poster, presentation or article (choose the appropriate one). The resource is probably unpublished (check that). If the resource is published, then complete publication name. Always complete event name.
Books and monographs are non-refereed and the title and publication name should be the same. Generally, they should have a status of published.
Books chapters are non-refereed and the title and publication name will be different. Generally, they should have a status of published.
NCAR monographs are non-refereed; have a status of published and should have a publication name.
NCAR books are non-refereed; have a status of published and should have a publication name.
NCAR manuscripts are non-refereed; have a status of published and should not have a publication name.
SOARS papers are non-refereed; have a status of unpublished and should not have a publication name.
Both OSGC and UCAR History contain a variety of resources such that each resource needs to be analyzed independently to determine whether it needs a publication name.
Capitalize the first word of a title and the first word of subtitles (e.g. An introduction to DART: A community facility for ensemble data assimilation).
Capitalize other words only as appropriate (e.g. Earth). Proper nouns, chemical abbreviations, instrument or model abbreviations, and the titles of conferences should also be capitalized.
Separate the title and the subtitle with a colon.

If the title indicates that the resource is a 'part' of a larger whole, capitalize the P and use either Roman or Arabic numerals, as indicated within the title of the resource itself (e.g. The art of painting: Part 3)

donts.practice: Do not complete publication name for abstracts, animations, artifacts, blog/emails, correspondence, images, manuscripts, notes, newsletters, posters, presentations.
Do not use publication name for most archival materials or oral histories.
Do not end the title with any form of punctuation, unless it is part of the title itself.
